Chapter 12, Part 12 on Discriminating Karma, as above, it is said that the bodhisattva who abides in samÄdhi, from what stage is he called one who abides in samÄdhi?
What is he called samÄdhi?
Verse:
From cultivating the karma of the excellent major marks, the bodhisattva attains the name of samÄdhi,
Born in good destinies and noble families, with complete male faculties and firm mindfulness.
Discussion:

From cultivating the karma that ripens in the thirty-two excellent major marks of a great man, the bodhisattva is then called one who abides in samÄdhi, because from this time until becoming a buddha, he is always born in good destinies and noble families, etc.
Being born in good destinies means being born in the human and heavenly realms, because in these realms one mostly practices good and it is excellent, thus they are called good destinies.
In good destinies, they are always born in noble families, namely the brÄhmaá¹‡a caste, or the ká¹£atriya caste, or the very wealthy brÄhmaá¹‡a caste.

In noble families, the faculties are either complete or incomplete, but these bodhisattvas always have superior faculties, always receive a male body, and do not become a woman, let alone receive a body such as a eunuch.
Life after life, they are always able to remember their past lives, and the good deeds they do are always without backsliding.
That is to say, in benefiting and delighting all sentient beings, at all times and in all skillful means, the mind is without weariness, called without backsliding.
Because of being without backsliding, therefore it is said to be firm.

Isn't it that before cultivating the karma for the excellent characteristics, the mind of enlightenment does not regress, and one should be established in the stage of abiding? Why is it that only at the stage of cultivating the karma for the excellent characteristics, is the bodhisattva said to receive the name of the stage of abiding?
At that time, humans and gods are just beginning to know it together, so previously it was only known by the gods.
Or at that time, he is certain to enter the samÄdhi of enlightenment, and first only realizes enlightenment, definitely not anything else.
What characteristics should one know in cultivating the karma for the excellent marks?
A verse says:
In JambudvÄ«pa, a male facing the Buddha, the Buddha's volitionally created form,
For the remaining one hundred kalpas, he cultivates each mark with a hundred merits.
The treatise says:
Bodhisattvas must be in JambudvÄ«pa in order to cultivate and attract the karma for the excellent marks, because the wisdom and keenness of this continent is the most outstanding.
They are only males, not females or others, because at that time they have already transcended the state of females and others.
This should not be said, because the meaning of always receiving a male body has already been shown in the previous verse.

If it is said that the previous statement creates this karma and always receives a male body, and now it is said to clarify that in creating this karma for the first time, one is also not a female or others, therefore there is a difference in meaning between this and the previous statement.
This refutation is unreasonable, because the meaning has already been established.

It has already been explained that one who has created this karma is not a woman, etc., and it is also clear that at the time of creating it, one is not a woman, etc., because one who is not a woman, etc., does not create this karma and then immediately change sex.

Karma that can summon the marvelous marks of a good and auspicious buddha must be able to summon it by relying on a pure body, and therefore this meaning is already established by the previous explanation.

When one creates this karma, one must be in the presence of a buddha, that is, one must personally see the special and marvelous major and minor marks of the unshared form body of a buddha, and one must have a desire to summon the volition that summons this kind of karma. Without being in the presence of a tathÄgata, one is not fit to create this karma.
This karma that summons the marvelous marks has only the Buddha as its object of volition, because the Buddha is the object of admiration and good qualities.
Karma that summons the marvelous marks is only volitionally created, not created through cultivation, because it is not of the realm of form.
It is not created through hearing, because it is weak.
It is also not innate, because it is created through added effort.
Because they are only obtained in the body that is perfected by the practice of giving and so on during three incalculable eons, they are only acquired through exertion and are not innate good.
Only the remaining one hundred eons are spent in creating and cultivating them, not many more, because this is the way it is for Buddhas-to-be.
Only the Blessed One ÅšÄkyamuni, when his effort was complete, was able to transcend nine eons, and the actions producing the excellent characteristics were completed in ninety-one eons.
Therefore the TathÄgata said to the village headman:
I remember that for ninety-one eons, I have not seen any family that gave me food and suffered any harm, only great benefits.
From this point on, he always remembered his past lives by their intrinsic nature, and therefore it is said that he remembers up to this point, but not before.
Each excellent characteristic is adorned with a hundred merits. Here, a hundred thoughts are called a hundred merits.

That is to say, when about to create each excellent characteristic, one first gives rise to fifty thoughts to purify the body vessel, and then one gives rise to the action that attracts one characteristic.
Later, he again generates fifty wholesome thoughts to adorn and attract the karma of rebirth, causing it to be perfected.
As for the fifty thoughts, they are based on the ten wholesome courses of action, with each course of action generating five thoughts.

As for the five thoughts associated with the first wholesome course of action of refraining from killing, they are: the thought of refraining from killing, the thought of encouraging others to refrain from killing, the thought of praising the refraining from killing, the thought of rejoicing in the refraining from killing, and the thought of dedicating the merit of refraining from killing towards liberation.
The same is true for the other wholesome courses of action up to right view, each with five thoughts.
Other masters say:
Based on the ten wholesome courses of action, each generates five grades of wholesome thoughts, inferior, etc., which occur sequentially, just as one cultivates the meditative absorptions.
Other masters say:

Based on the ten wholesome courses of action, each generates five thoughts: the thought of pure preparatory action, the thought of pure fundamental action, the thought of pure subsequent action, the thought of not being harmed by discursive thought, and the thought of being embraced by mindfulness.
Other masters say:

Each of the characteristics of the wholesome courses of action serves as the condition for the Buddha to generate thoughts that he has never experienced before, and these one hundred thoughts manifest and adorn him.
What is the measure of each of the hundred merits?
Some say:
Based on the merit accumulated over three incalculable eons, he gave rise to such unobstructed and innumerable supreme blessings. Only the Buddha knows its measure.
Some say:
If by the power of karma one attains the position of a wheel-turning king, ruling the four continents with sovereignty, this is the measure of one blessing.
Some say:
If by the power of karma one becomes Åšakra, ruling the two desire heavens with sovereignty, this is the measure of one blessing.
Some say: Except for the blessings cultivated by bodhisattvas close to Buddhahood, the blessings cultivated by all other beings for the sake of wealth and happiness are the measure of one blessing.
Other masters say:
This measure is too small. It should be said that when the world is about to form, the merit of all beings that gives rise to the great trichiliocosm is the measure of one blessing.
How many Buddhas did the Blessed One worship during each of the three incalculable eons when he was a bodhisattva?
Verse:
In the three incalculable eons, each he made offerings to 70,000,
And again in order he made offerings to 6,000, 7,000 Buddhas.
The treatise says:

In the first incalculable eon, he made offerings to 75,000 Buddhas. In the second incalculable eon, he made offerings to 76,000 Buddhas. In the last incalculable eon, he made offerings to 77,000 Buddhas.
When each of the three incalculable eons was fulfilled, and when he first gave rise to the resolve, what Buddhas did he encounter?
The verse says:
When the three incalculable eons were fulfilled, he encountered VipaÅ›yin,
DÄ«paá¹ƒkara, RatnaÅ›ikhin Buddha, and first ÅšÄkyamuni.
The treatise says:

As for in reverse order, it refers from later to earlier. That is to say, at the fulfillment of the third incalculable eon, the Buddha he encountered was named VipaÅ›yin. At the fulfillment of the second eon, the Buddha he encountered was named DÄ«paá¹ƒkara. At the fulfillment of the first eon, the Buddha he encountered was named RatnaÅ›ikhin. At the beginning of the first incalculable eon, he first encountered ÅšÄkyamuni.

It is said that when our World-Honored One first generated the mind of enlightenment, he encountered a BhagavÄn named ÅšÄkyamuni. When that Buddha appeared in the world, he was in the final eon. After his extinction, the true Dharma remained for only a thousand years.

At that time, our World-Honored One was the son of a potter. He gave rise to a sincere and pure mind towards that Buddha, anointed him with fragrant oil, bathed him with fragrant water, made offerings, and then made a great vow:
May I become a Buddha just like the World-Honored One now.
Therefore, the TathÄgata is now exactly the same as him.
In what stage did our ÅšÄkyamuni Bodhisattva fully cultivate and perfect the pÄramitÄs?
The verse says:
Merely out of compassion, he universally gave, his body was cut apart without anger,
He praised Buddha DÄ«paá¹ƒkara, next, unsurpassed enlightenment,
The six pÄramitÄs, in these four stages,
One, two, and again one, two, are cultivated and perfected in sequence.

When a bodhisattva first generates the vow and practices giving, he is not yet able to give all things to all sentient beings. He only generates a mind of compassion. Later, through the power of repeated practice, his mind of compassion increases and he is able to give to all sentient beings, although not all things.

When a bodhisattva universally gives all things to all sentient beings, only because of a mind of compassion, not because he himself seeks a superior rebirth, at that time the perfection of giving is completed.
Some say:

A bodhisattva observes that the world is lacking in wealth and is oppressed by poverty and suffering. In order to benefit them, he also generates a mind of compassion and vows to seek a superior rebirth for himself. This is because bodhisattvas never at any time fail to generate a mind of compassion when practicing giving.

When a bodhisattva is having his body cut up and although he has not yet eliminated the craving of desire, his mind has not the slightest anger, at that time the perfections of morality and patience are completed.
One who is replete with patience has no anger in his mind toward those sentient beings.
As for the perfection of morality, one does not give rise to the bodily and verbal actions of harming others.
Because the mind is without anger, and because the body and speech are without evil, when there is no anger, the perfection of morality and patience is fulfilled.
When the bodhisattva was vigorously practicing diligence, praising DÄ«paá¹ƒkara, he immediately surpassed nine kalpas. Diligence pÄramitÄ was cultivated and perfected to this extent.
In the past, there was a buddha named DÄ«paá¹ƒkara. That buddha had two bodhisattva disciples:
One was named ÅšÄkyamuni, and the other was named Maitreya.

The Buddha, because of observing the fields to be transformed by himself, clearly illuminated and knew that these two disciples, while able to transform others, were first ripe themselves, not those to be transformed. Maitreya was first ripe himself, not those to be transformed.
Knowing this, he further thought like this:
Quickly ripening one's own body is a small and easy matter.
He then used skillful means to enter a jeweled chamber, cross his legs in meditation, and sit. Relying on the supreme samÄdhi, the unique qualities of a buddha manifested everywhere before him.

When he saw that Buddha, his majestic light was especially brilliant and extraordinary. He suddenly had a pure mind, held himself up, and stood on one foot for seven days and nights, praising that Buddha with wonderful verses, saying:

Like the bull king, the great Å›ramaá¹‡a. Searching the earth, mountains, and forests, there is no equal.
Having praised in this way, he immediately surpassed nine kalpas, and before Maitreya, he realized supreme enlightenment.

When the Bodhisattva was on the vajra seat, about to ascend to supreme perfect enlightenment, he next abided in the vajra-like samÄdhi before supreme enlightenment. At this point, the perfections of concentration and wisdom were fully cultivated.

Reason dictates that at this stage, immediately upon attaining the knowledge of completion, this [perfection of wisdom] is fulfilled, because it separately and individually reaches the other shore of perfect virtue.
These six are called perfections.
The sÅ«tras speak of three meritorious deeds:
The first is the meritorious action of giving, the second is the meritorious action of morality, and the third is the meritorious action of cultivation.
How are they established as meritorious actions?
Verse:
The three types of giving, morality, and cultivation, each according to its proper function,
Are called meritorious actions. The distinctions are like the paths of action.
Treatise:
The three types are all meritorious, either action or events, according to their proper function, as explained in the paths of action.

That is to say, just as in the analysis of the ten paths of action, there is action that is also a path, and there are paths that are not action. Herein, there is that which is meritorious, action, and event; there is that which is meritorious and action but not an event; there is that which is meritorious and an event but not action; and there is that which is only meritorious, neither action nor an event.

First, in the type of giving, the two actions of body and speech are fully endowed with the three meanings of meritorious action. Because they are good, they are meritorious. Because they are created, they are also action. Because they are the gateway for the arising and transformation of the volition that gives rise to bodily and verbal actions, they are also called events.

The volition that is concomitant with it is called meritorious action, and the dharmas that are concomitant with it are called meritorious action. Since the class of morality is only by nature bodily and vocal action, it is called meritorious action and meritorious activity.
Among the class of cultivation, loving-kindness is only called meritorious activity, because it is the activity of merit.

The volition associated with loving-kindness is called meritorious action, because it is created through loving-kindness as the gateway. The morality of volition concomitant with loving-kindness is called meritorious action.
The other concomitant dharmas are only called merit.
Compassion and so forth should all be examined in the same way.
Some say that meritorious action shows the meaning of creating merit, that is, the preparatory stage of merit.
Activity shows the basis, that is, giving, morality, and cultivation are the activities of meritorious action, because the preparatory stage of merit is created in order to accomplish those three.
Some say:
Only volition is true meritorious action. The activities of meritorious action are giving, morality, and cultivation, because meritorious action arises through the three as gateways.
What dharma is called giving?
What result does giving bring?
The verse says:
By this, abandoning is called giving, that is, for the sake of offering and benefiting,
this attracts the fruit of great wealth.
The treatise says:

Although the objects given away and the means of giving can both be called giving, in this context the name giving is established only based on the means of giving. That is to say, because by this means the act of giving can be accomplished, the basis of giving is the true substance of giving.
Just as the object to be measured does not get the name measure, the name measure is established based on the means of measuring.

Or for the sake of victory, storage, praise, transmission, following others, affection, or association, the act of giving is also accomplished by such means, but this is not the main point being discussed here. In order to exclude those, the words for the sake of worship and for the sake of benefit are said. For those who have entered nirvana, it is only for the sake of worship. For others, it is also for the sake of benefit.
When the great elements and faculties are given, it is only for the sake of benefiting them. What is the name of the means of giving?
It refers to bodily and verbal actions and what gives rise to them.
What is meant by what gives rise to them?

That is, the aggregate of dharmas that can give rise to this aggregate, namely, bodily and verbal actions, the mind that gives rise to them, and the dharmas associated with them, are all called the substance of giving.
As a verse says:
If a person, with a pure mind, gives up what belongs to himself and practices giving,
This momentary wholesome aggregate is generally established as giving.
You should know that this kind of meritorious action of giving, even if dedicated to liberation, also obtains the fruit of separation.
However, based on what is close and certain, it is said that it can only attract the fruit of great wealth.
Based on what is this great wealth established?
Because wealth is wonderful, extensive, and cannot be taken away.
Giving that is superior in one corner, wounded by poison and thorns, although given, does not have the fruit of great wealth.
The term giving is used to show that giving is the substance.
Just as clay is the substance of vessels and wood is the substance of pillars, the term kind is also seen, but it does not show the meaning of substance.
Like the knowledge of what is heard, which is not accepted now, the terms kind of precepts and cultivation should be explained according to this.
For what benefit does one practice giving?
Verse:
For the benefit of self, others, both, and neither, one practices giving.
Commentary:

When the donor gives, they consider two benefits: first, benefiting themselves by giving rise to wholesome roots that will bring about results; second, benefiting others by providing for the growth of their faculties and elements.
There are two kinds of donors:
those with afflictions and those without afflictions.
Those with afflictions are of two kinds:
those who have not yet abandoned craving for desire and those who have already abandoned craving for desire.
Within these two, there are two kinds each:
those who are noble ones and those who are ordinary beings.

Among them, the noble ones who have not yet abandoned craving for desire, and the ordinary beings who have not yet abandoned craving for desire, when making offerings to stupas, only benefit themselves.

That is to say, they increase two kinds of wholesome roots within themselves: first, they are able to attract great wealth as a result; second, they serve as provisions for attaining the supreme meaning.
When holy beings who have already freed themselves from attachment make offerings to stupas, they do not invite great wealth, because they have already transcended the realm of retribution.
However, they are able to serve as a supply of superior meaning, and for that reason it is said that they are only for their own benefit.
Because they do not benefit others, they do not benefit others.

When those who are free from the passions make offerings to other sentient beings, they only benefit others, because they are able to benefit the faculties and the primary elements of others, but they do not increase the two kinds of wholesome roots, and for that reason they do not benefit themselves.
When those who are not free from the passions make offerings to other sentient beings, they benefit both.
When those who are free from the passions make offerings to stupas, they do not benefit both, because they do not invite retribution.
There is an opinion that only the invitation of great wealth is distinguished in the results of giving. That opinion is expressed as follows:

In this context, all ordinary beings who have not yet abandoned desire and those who have abandoned desire, when they offer their possessions to the caitya, this giving is called only for one's own benefit, because they do not benefit by it.

If the noble ones who have already abandoned desire give to sentient beings, excluding that which produces results in the present life, this giving is called only for the benefit of others, because they benefit by it, and because they transcend the stage of results.
If all those who have not yet abandoned desire and those who have abandoned desire, when they offer their possessions to sentient beings, this giving is called for the benefit of both.

If those noble ones who have already abandoned desire offer to the caitya, excluding that which produces results in the present life, this giving is called not for the benefit of both, because it is only for the purpose of making offerings and repaying kindness.
Previously, it was generally stated that giving leads to great wealth. Now, the specific causes of the results of giving will be discussed.
In verse it is said:
The fruits of giving are distinguished due to the differences in the giver, the object given, and the field.
The treatise says:

Giving has distinctions due to three kinds of causes, namely, because of the differences in the giver, the object given, and the field, and because of the distinctions in giving, the fruits have distinctions.

As for the differences in the giver, the object given, and the field, it means that the superiority and inferiority of this kind of giver, object given, and field are different from other givers, objects given, and fields.
First, as for the differences in the giver, the verse says:
The giver is different due to faith, etc., practicing respectful giving, etc.,
Obtaining respect, vast love, timely, and difficult to take away fruits.
The treatise says:

There are donors who have definite faith in cause and effect, there are donors who are uncertain in their minds about cause and effect, there are donors who act on impulse or according to their desires, there are donors who possess pure precepts, some who violate them slightly, and some who have no precepts at all, there are donors who are well-versed in the Buddha's teachings, some who are less learned, and some who have no learning at all, yet they practice giving.
Due to the differences in the merits possessed by donors, such as faith, precepts, learning, etc., it is called difference in the master.
Because of the difference in the master, giving becomes differentiated.
Due to the differentiation in giving, the attainment of fruits is different.

Those donors who possess such virtues and are able to practice the four types of giving such as respectful giving in accordance with the Dharma, will subsequently attain the four fruits such as being respected by others.
That is to say, if a donor practices respectful giving, they will always be respected by others.
If one gives with one's own hands, one will be able to attain vast wealth and enjoy it with delight.
If one gives at the proper time, one will obtain wealth at the proper time, because what is needed is at the proper time, not at other times.
If one gives without harming others, one will obtain wealth that is not destroyed by kings, fires, etc.
As for the differences in the wealth that is given, the verse states:
The differences in wealth are due to color, etc. One obtains a wonderful color and a good reputation.
The body is loved by the multitude and soft, with pleasant tactile sensations in accordance with the season.
The treatise states:
If the wealth that is given lacks or possesses color, smell, taste, and touch, one will accordingly obtain the fruits of a wonderful color, etc., either lacking or possessing them.
This means that because the color of the wealth given is complete, one will obtain a wonderful color.
Because the smell is complete, one will obtain a good reputation, just as a fragrant scent pervades all directions.
Because the taste is complete, one will be loved by the multitude, just as a delicious taste is loved by the multitude.
Because the touch is complete, one will obtain a soft body and tactile sensations that give rise to pleasant feelings in accordance with the season.
If any of these are lacking, the corresponding fruit will be diminished. In this way, giving is also distinguished by the distinction of its objects, such as color, smell, etc.
Because of the distinction of objects, the substance of giving and its fruit are all distinguished.
As for the distinction of the field of giving, a verse says:
The field is distinguished by realm, suffering, kindness, and virtue.
The treatise says:
The field of giving is distinguished by realm, suffering, kindness, and virtue. Therefore, it is called the distinction of the field.
Because of the distinction of the field, the fruit of giving is distinguished.
As for the distinction of realm, the World-Honored One said:
If one gives to animals, one receives a hundredfold fruit. If one gives to those who violate precepts, one receives a thousandfold fruit.
How is the measure of a hundredfold or a thousandfold fruit?

According to the field of giving, by causing their life span, etc. to increase by that much, the giver, because of this, in the human and heavenly realms receives an equal or superior hundredfold or thousandfold.
Therefore, the World-Honored One said:
When the donor gives, the five things such as lifespan of the recipient of the gift are given. The donor, by this, will obtain in the human and heavenly realms the five fruits such as lifespan.

Due to the difference in suffering, as in the seven types of meritorious deeds with basis, it is said that one should give to guests, the sick, attendants, gardens, forests, regular meals, and clothing and medicine according to the season such as cold and wind.
It is also said:
If there is a man or woman of pure faith who accomplishes these seven types of meritorious deeds with basis, the merit they obtain cannot be measured.
Here, the suffering is different due to the difference in conditions, and the fruit has a difference due to the difference in the exclusion of the recipient's suffering.
Due to the difference in kindness, as in parents, teachers, and others who are kind, such as the bears, deer, etc. mentioned in the JÄtakas.
The fruit of the evil deeds done to those who are kind is presently knowable, and by this one infers that the fruit of the good deeds of repaying kindness is certain.
As for the distinction of virtue, a scripture says:
The fruit of giving to one who observes precepts is a hundred thousand times greater, and so on up to the fruit of giving to a Buddha, which is immeasurable.
Although all are immeasurable, there is still a little more or less, like the water drops in the Ganges and the great ocean.
Like comparing material giving, the giving of Dharma is supreme.
Within material giving, what is the most excellent?
A verse says:
Liberating those who are liberated and bodhisattvas, the eighth giving is most excellent.
The treatise says:
If one who is already liberated gives to a field of liberation, this is the most excellent among material gifts.

If bodhisattvas, with a superior intention, equally wish to benefit all beings and practice giving for the sake of great enlightenment, although it is not giving to the liberated or a field of liberation, this giving of merit is the most excellent.
Apart from this, among the eight kinds of giving, the eighth giving of merit is also the most excellent.
What are the eight kinds of giving?

The first is giving according to one's ability, the second is giving out of fear, the third is giving in return for a favor, the fourth is giving in expectation of a reward, the fifth is giving in imitation of one's ancestors, the sixth is giving in the hope of going to heaven, the seventh is giving in order to gain a good reputation, and the eighth is giving in order to adorn the mind, to assist the mind, to assist yoga, and to attain the supreme meaning.
Giving according to one's ability means giving clothes and food according to one's ability to those who come seeking, without deep respect.
Giving out of fear means practicing giving in order to bring about peace when seeing calamity and misfortune.
Or seeing that this thing is about to be destroyed, it is better to give it away than to lose it, so one practices giving.
Giving in imitation of one's ancestors means practicing giving in imitation of the family traditions of one's ancestors.
In order to adorn the mind means practicing giving in order to arouse the holy wealth of faith and so forth.
Assisting the mind means practicing giving in order to eliminate the defilements of stinginess and greed.
Supporting yoga refers to seeking the joy of concentration, which arises in succession, and practicing generosity.
This is because by giving, one attains non-regret, and so on, up to one-pointedness of mind.
Attaining the supreme meaning refers to attaining nirvana, because by first abandoning wealth and so on, up to all cyclic existence, one is able to abandon them all.
Moreover, practicing generosity is the cause for supreme rebirth, because it can lead to the realization of the Dharma that attains nirvana.
The other types of generosity are easy to understand, so they are not explained separately.
As the World-Honored One said, the fruits of generosity towards the noble ones are immeasurable. Can there be generosity towards non-noble ones whose fruits are also immeasurable?
The verse says:
Parents, the sick, Dharma teachers, and bodhisattvas in their final birth,
Even if they are not those who have realized the noble truths, the fruits of generosity towards them are also immeasurable.
The treatise says:
These five types, even if they are ordinary beings, if one gives to them, it can also bring immeasurable fruits.
One who abides in their final existence is called a bodhisattva in their final birth. Among the four fields of merit, to which field do they belong?
This is because it includes the field of blessings and virtue.
Why is this so?

Because the Dharma teacher can show those who are about to fall into the evil destinies the gate to the city of safety and security, and can reveal the path to rebirth in the heavens and liberation. He can cause those who have already engaged in improper conduct to turn to proper conduct, and can skillfully proclaim the nature, fruits, and antidotes of the black and white categories of dharmas. He can bestow the eye of wisdom to the blind of ignorance.
Because by the power of the teachings expounded by the Dharma teacher, one can observe the categories of defilement and purity without error.
In brief, the excellent Dharma teacher can even perform the duties of the Buddha, and therefore this is the ultimate field of blessings and virtue. The giver will certainly reap immeasurable fruits.
Do all karmas that can produce immeasurable fruits equally belong to the superior or inferior categories?
No, they do not.
How is it then?
All karmas become superior or inferior due to six causes.
What are the six?
The verse states:
The subsequent action, the field, the fundamental, the preparatory action, the intention, and the attitude,
By these, the lower and upper, the karma becomes lower and upper grades.
The treatise says:
The subsequent action refers to either suddenly or frequently following the previous action after having done this action.
The field refers to creating good or creating evil towards them.
The fundamental refers to the fundamental karmic paths.
The preparatory action refers to leading the body and speech.
The intention refers to the completion of the karmic path by this.
The attitude refers to all the intentions, thinking I should create such and such.
If there are six causes that are all upper grades, this karma is the heaviest. The opposite of this is the lightest. Apart from this, the middle is neither the lightest nor the heaviest.
This means that there may be karma that is only included in the subsequent action, and therefore becomes a heavy grade, because it definitely establishes the result of retribution for that.
Up to there may be only the attitude.
By two, three, and so forth, one should understand according to reason.
As the sutra says:
Deliberate reflection on the performance of action is called creation and also called increase.
For what reason is action said to be called increase?
Because of five causes.
What are the five?
Verse:
Because of careful consideration, completion, absence of regret and counteraction,
Accompaniment, and retribution, this action is called increase.
The treatise says:
Because of careful consideration means that it is done with careful consideration, not done with a sudden thought, and not done without any thought at all.
Because of completion means that up to this extent, action should fall into an evil realm. This completed action is called increase, the rest are only creation.
